facts.text: On 4th October 1968 at about 5 p.m. the appellant was found standing near the crossing of Yusuf Meherally Road and Abdul Rahman Street adjoining Crawford Market in Bombay.

The movements of the appellant excited the suspicion of PSI Bhambre and Police Constable Vithal Bapu Kamble, who accosted the appellant and asked why he was standing there. Appellant replied he was waiting for a friend.

Officers searched the appellant in presence of panchas and found two paper packets, one in each trouser pocket, each containing ten brand new wrist-watches of Sandoz manufacture, value over Rs. 2,000/-.
Appellant unable to give satisfactory explanation for possession of wrist-watches.
Appellant charged under section 124 of the Bombay Police Act, 1951 before Presidency Magistrate V.T., Bombay.

Presidency Magistrate convicted appellant under section 124, sentenced to rigorous imprisonment for three months and fine of Rs. 100 or in default further RI for fifteen days, holding reason to believe wrist-watches were stolen or fraudulently obtained and explanation unsatisfactory.

Appellant appealed to Bombay High Court (Crl. Appeal No. 278 of 1969). Single Judge (Kamat, J.) viewed wrist-watches as smuggled property fraudulently obtained, disagreed with Pratap Baburao, referred to Division Bench.

Division Bench (Palekar and S. K. Desai, JJ.) disagreed with Vimadalal, J., held section 124 requires property to be of character 'stolen property or property fraudulently obtained' regardless of by whom, confirmed conviction as explanation unsatisfactory.
High Court granted certificate under Article 134(1)(c) as involved interpretation of section 124.
Appellant not a dealer in wrist-watches, found with twenty brand new foreign manufacture wrist-watches in trouser pockets.

legal_issues.text: True interpretation of section 124 of Bombay Police Act, 1951: whether 'property fraudulently obtained' requires it to be fraudulently obtained by the accused, or is it sufficient that the property bears the character of stolen property or property fraudulently obtained by whomsoever.

petitioner_arguments.text: Even if wrist-watches were smuggled goods, they could not be said to be fraudulently obtained, and in any event no evidence to show they were fraudulently obtained by the appellant.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: Reliance on Pratap Baburao v. State of Maharashtra by Vimadalal, J.

petitioner_arguments.text: Prosecution case in regard to second ingredient not established.

respondent_arguments.text: There was reason to believe wrist-watches were smuggled property and hence property fraudulently obtained; explanation by appellant unsatisfactory.

court_reasoning.text: Three ingredients of section 124: (1) accused in possession etc.; (2) reason to believe property stolen or fraudulently obtained; (3) fails to account satisfactorily. All satisfied here.
court_reasoning.key_observation: First ingredient satisfied as twenty brand new wrist-watches found in possession.

court_reasoning.text: Reason to believe wrist-watches smuggled: appellant not dealer, brand new foreign watches in trouser pockets, no explanation how obtained.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Smuggled goods are property fraudulently obtained by committing fraud on import/customs regulations.

court_reasoning.text: Section does not require property stolen/fraudulently obtained 'by him'; describes character of property, regardless by whom stolen/obtained. If required by accused, would be redundant with IPC/Customs Act etc.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Plain language: 'stolen property or property fraudulently obtained' without 'by him'. Court not concerned if by accused.

court_reasoning.text: Explanation for possession unsatisfactory, third ingredient satisfied.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Appellant failed to account to satisfaction of court.

holdings.text: Section 124 requires reason to believe property is stolen or fraudulently obtained (its character), not necessarily by the accused; possession of such property without satisfactory account is offence.
All three ingredients satisfied; appellant rightly convicted under section 124.

precedents_cited.case_name: Pratap Baburao v. The State of Maharashtra
precedents_cited.relevance: Vimadalal, J. held section 124 requires reason to believe property fraudulently obtained by accused; disagreed with by single judge, Division Bench and Supreme Court.

statutes_cited.name: Bombay Police Act, 1951
statutes_cited.relevance: Interpreted to penalize possession of property there is reason to believe is stolen or fraudulently obtained, without satisfactory account; ingredients outlined.

statutes_cited.name: Constitution of India
statutes_cited.relevance: Certificate granted by High Court for appeal to Supreme Court.

statutes_cited.name: Indian Penal Code
statutes_cited.relevance: Distinct offence if accused stole or fraudulently obtained property.

outcome.summary: Appeal dismissed, conviction and sentence under section 124 Bombay Police Act confirmed.

key_quotes.text: "The expression fraudulently obtained like the other juxtaposed expression stolen in that same section is the attribute, stamp or character of the property found in the possession of accused."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Division Bench view adopted by Supreme Court on interpretation of section 124.

key_quotes.text: "Smuggled goods are clearly goods fraudulently obtained."
key_quotes.speaker: court

key_quotes.text: "The section merely speaks of the character of the property-whether it satisfies the particular description and does not say by whom it should have been stolen or fraudulently obtained."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Core holding on why no need for accused to have obtained it fraudulently.
